tit.e: Takeda no miko (the Imperial Prince Takeda)
tit.cmt: カッコ部分を補いました。
tit.e: Takeda no miko (the Imperial Prince Takeda)

sen.j: 竹田皇子（たけだのみこ、生没年不詳）は、飛鳥時代の皇族。
sen.e: Takeda no miko (date of birth and death unknown) was a member of the Imperial family in the Asuka period.
Takeda no miko (date of birth and death unknown) was a member of the Imperial Family in the Asuka period.
sen.cmt: Imperial family→Imperial Family と修正しました。
sen.e: Takeda no miko (date of birth and death unknown) was a member of the Imperial Family in the Asuka period.

sen.j: 父は敏達天皇、母は皇后推古天皇（推古天皇）。
sen.e: His father was Emperor Bidatsu and mother was Empress Suiko (Empress Suiko).
His father was the Emperor Bidatsu and mother was the Empress Suiko (Empress Suiko).
His father was the Emperor Bidatsu and mother was the Empress Suiko (Empress Suiko).

sen.j: 名前の由来は葛城地方の地名から。
sen.e: His name was taken after the Kazuragi region.
His name is derived from a place in the Kazuragi region.
sen.cmt: was taken after→is derived from と修正しました。「地名から」という部分を補いました。
sen.e: His name is derived from a place in the Kazuragi region.
He was also called Takeda no okimi, Okai no miko.
He was also called Takeda no okimi, or Okai no miko.
He was also called Takeda no okimi, or Okai no miko.

sen.j: 用明天皇の崩御後押坂彦人大兄皇子と共に有力皇位継承権者であったと日本書紀等では記されているが、穴穂部皇子を推す勢力から敵視され、用明天皇2年（587年）にはその一派である中臣勝海に像を作り呪詛されている。
sen.e: Although "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan) reported that he was a leading successor to the imperial throne together with Oshisaka no Hikohito no Oenomiko after the death of Emperor Yomei, a powerful party supporting Prince Anahobe regarded him with hostility, and he was cursed by NAKATOMI no Katsumi, a member of a party using a statue in 587.

Although Nihonshoki (Chronicles of Japan) reported that he was a leading successor to the imperial throne together with Oshisaka no Hikohito no Oenomiko after the death of the Emperor Yomei, a powerful party supporting the Prince Anahobe regarded him as hostile, and he was cursed by NAKATOMI no Katsumi, a member of the party by making a statue of him in 587.
sen.cmt: クォーツ, を削除しました。the を補いました。with hostility→as hostile,a→the,using a statue→by making a statue of him と修正しました。
sen.e: Although Nihonshoki (Chronicles of Japan) reported that he was a leading successor to the imperial throne together with Oshisaka no Hikohito no Oenomiko after the death of the Emperor Yomei, a powerful party supporting the Prince Anahobe regarded him as hostile, and he was cursed by NAKATOMI no Katsumi, a member of the party by making a statue of him in 587.

sen.j: 当時勢力を拡大していた蘇我氏にとって、蘇我稲目の孫にあたる炊屋姫から生まれた竹田皇子が即位すると蘇我氏の権勢を増大させるのに有利に運ぶ事から早くから皇位継承の有力候補と目されていた。
sen.e: The Soga clan, expanding their influence at that time, considered Takeda no miko, his mother, Kashiyaki hime was a granddaughter of SOGA no Iname, as the favorite successor to alter the situation to their advantage to increase in their power.

Since the enthronement of Takeda no miko, the son of Kashiyaki hime, a granddaughter of SOGA no Iname, benefited the Soga clan who was expanding its influence at the time to grow even bigger, the prince had been considered as a prominent candidate from his early stage.
sen.cmt: 文脈に応じて全体的に修正しました。
sen.e: Since the enthronement of Takeda no miko, the son of Kashiyaki hime, a granddaughter of SOGA no Iname, benefited the Soga clan who was expanding its influence at the time to grow even bigger, the prince had been considered as a prominent candidate from his early stage.

sen.j: 敏達天皇崩御時には皇子は幼少であった事や異母兄である押坂彦人大兄皇子を擁立する動きもあった為即位が見送られ敏達天皇の皇兄弟、用明天皇が即位する。
sen.e: When Emperor Bidatsu died, he was still young and there was a movement to put his older paternal half-brother,Oshisaka no Hikohito no Oenomiko on the imperial throne, his enthronement was passed over and Emperor Yomei, a brother of Emperor Bidatsu, ascended to the imperial throne.

Since the prince was too young when the Emperor Bidatsu died and there was a movement to support Oshisaka no Hikohito no Oenomiko, his older paternal half-brother to enthrone; his enthronement was given up then the Emperor Yomei, the brother of the Emperor Bidatsu was enthroned.
sen.cmt: the を補いました。よりスムースに修正しました。
sen.e: Since the prince was too young when the Emperor Bidatsu died and there was a movement to support Oshisaka no Hikohito no Oenomiko, his older paternal half-brother to enthrone; his enthronement was given up then the Emperor Yomei, the brother of the Emperor Bidatsu was enthroned.

sen.j: これが用明天皇だが、天皇は即位後僅か2年で崩御してしまう。
sen.e: This is how Emperor Yomei assumed the throne, but he died just two years after the enthronement.
This is how the Emperor Yomei assumed the throne, but he died just two years after the enthronement.
This is how the Emperor Yomei assumed the throne, but he died just two years after the enthronement.

sen.j: これにより蘇我氏と物部氏による皇位継承を巡る争いに発展する。
sen.e: His death caused discord between the Soga clan and the Mononobe clan over the succession to the Imperial throne.
His death developed the conflict between the Soga clan and the Mononobe clan over the imperial succession.
sen.cmt: caused discord→developed the conflict,succession to the imperial throne→imperial succession と修正しました。
sen.e: His death developed the conflict between the Soga clan and the Mononobe clan over the imperial succession.

sen.j: 皇子は蘇我馬子と物部守屋との合戦の際には崇峻天皇（崇峻天皇）、厩戸皇子（聖徳太子）、難波皇子、春日皇子と共に馬子側について従軍した。
sen.e: The prince joined the Soga clan's army together with Emperor Sushun, Prince Umayado (Prince Shotoku), Prince Naniwa and Kasuga no Miko at the battle between SOGA no Umako and MONONOBE no Moriya.
Takeda no miko joined Umako side at the battle between SOGA no Umako and MONONOBE no Moriya, fought with the Emperor Sushun, the Prince Umayado (Prince Shotoku), the Prince Naniwa and Kasuga no Miko.
sen.cmt: the, カンマを補いました。The prince→Takeda no miko,the Soga clan's army→Umako side,together→fought,オーダーを修正しました。
sen.e: Takeda no miko joined Umako side at the battle between SOGA no Umako and MONONOBE no Moriya, fought with the Emperor Sushun, the Prince Umayado (Prince Shotoku), the Prince Naniwa and Kasuga no Miko.

sen.j: この合戦後に泊瀬部皇子は即位するが、竹田皇子は史料から登場しなくなる。
sen.e: After this battle, Prince Hatsusebe assumed the imperial throne, but Takeda no miko disappeared from historical documents.
After this battle, the Prince Hatsusebe assumed the imperial throne, but Takeda no miko disappeared from historical documents.
After this battle, the Prince Hatsusebe assumed the imperial throne, but Takeda no miko disappeared from historical documents.

sen.j: 恐らくこの前後に薨去したものと思われる。
sen.e: It is assumed that he died during this battle.
It is assumed that he died around this time.
sen.cmt: during→around（”前後”）,battle→time と修正しました。
sen.e: It is assumed that he died around this time.

sen.j: また、一説には崇峻天皇即位時、推古天皇即位時には竹田皇子が未だ成年に達していなかった為即位が見送られ、推古天皇即位後間も無く薨去したため厩戸皇子立太子となったともいう。
sen.e: One theory is that when Emperor Sushun and Emperor Suiko ascended the imperial throne, his enthronement was passed over since he was a minor, and he died soon after Emperor Suiko assumed the throne, so that he became the Crown prince Umayado (厩戸皇子立太子).

According to a theory, both the Emperor Sushun and the Empress Suiko were enthroned due to the fact that Takeda no miko was still a minor, then he became the Crown prince Umayado (厩戸皇子立太子) since he died soon after the enthronement of the Empress Suiko.
sen.cmt: 文脈に応じて修正しました。
sen.e: According to a theory, both the Emperor Sushun and the Empress Suiko were enthroned due to the fact that Takeda no miko was still a minor, then he became the Crown prince Umayado (厩戸皇子立太子) since he died soon after the enthronement of the Empress Suiko.

sen.j: 皇子の墓は日本書紀に推古天皇が竹田皇子の墓に合葬するように遺詔した事から、推古天皇陵として治定されている磯長山田陵(大阪府南河内郡太子町 (大阪府)大字山田)とされる（書紀は陵墓名を記さず）。
sen.e: Since "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan) reported that Empress Suiko wished in her will to be buried in Takeda no miko's graveyard, it is said that his graveyard is Shinaga no Yamada no Misasagi (the Yamada Imperial tomb) (Taishi-cho, Minamikawachi County, Osaka Prefecture) was designated as the burial mound of Empress Suiko ("Nihonshoki" didn't recorded name of burial mound).

Since "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan) reported that the Empress Suiko wished in her will to be buried in Takeda no miko's graveyard, it is said that his graveyard is Shinaga no Yamada no Misasagi (the Yamada Imperial tomb) (Oaza Yamada, Taishi-cho, Minamikawachi-gun, Osaka Prefecture), designated as the burial mound of the Empress Suiko (The "Nihonshoki" did not record the name of the burial mound.)
sen.cmt: the, カンマを補いました。スペースを修正しました。Minamikawachi County→Minamikawachi-gun,was designated→designated と修正しました。「大字山田」を補いました。カッコ内、ピリオドの位置を修正しました。
sen.e: Since "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan) reported that the Empress Suiko wished in her will to be buried in Takeda no miko's graveyard, it is said that his graveyard is Shinaga no Yamada no Misasagi (the Yamada Imperial tomb) (Oaza Yamada, Taishi-cho, Minamikawachi-gun, Osaka Prefecture), designated as the burial mound of the Empress Suiko (The "Nihonshoki" did not record the name of the burial mound.)

sen.j: 近年では奈良県橿原市五条野町にある植山古墳が古事記に見える一時合葬していた大野岡上陵とされている。
sen.e: Recently, Ueyama Tumulus in Gojono, Kashihara City, Nara Prefecture is considered as the Mausoleum of Ono no okanoue where "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters) reported Takeda no miko and Empress Suiko were jointly buried temporarily.

Recently, the Ueyama Tumulus in Gojono-cho, Kashihara City, Nara Prefecture is considered as the Mausoleum of Ono no okanoue, where the "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters) reported Takeda no miko and the Empress Suiko were jointly buried temporarily.
sen.cmt: the, カンマを補いました。Gojono→Gojono-cho と修正しました。
sen.e: Recently, the Ueyama Tumulus in Gojono-cho, Kashihara City, Nara Prefecture is considered as the Mausoleum of Ono no okanoue, where the "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters) reported Takeda no miko and the Empress Suiko were jointly buried temporarily.
